name: Lost for Words! 6 Quiz | Lyrics Mixture | 10 Questions

questions.text:
Which word is missing from this classic lyric?

"I was only twenty four hours from Tulsa 
only one day away from your ______ ."
questions.explanation:
arms.

	"Twenty Four Hours From Tulsa" was a 1963 hit for Gene Pitney. The song was written by Burt Bacharach and Hal David.Gene Francis Alan Pitney was born in Connecticut in 1941.

questions.text:
"We are family 
I got all my ______ with me 
We are family 
Get up everybody and sing." 

Which family word completes this lyric?
questions.explanation:
sisters.

	These lyrics come from the Sister Sledge track "We Are Family", which was released in 1979.Sisters Debra, Joan, Kim and Kathy Sledge formed the group in Philadelphia in 1971.

questions.text:
"It's been a hard day's night, 
and I been _______ like a dog"

Familiar words, but which one is missing?
questions.explanation:
working.

	"A Hard Day's Night" was written by John Lennon and Paul McCartney. The Beatles topped the US and UK charts with this song in 1964."A Hard Day's Night" was just one of seven hit singles for the Fab Four in 1964.

questions.text:
"I know there's only, only one like you 
Theres no way they could have made two 
Girl you're my reality 
But I'm lost in a dream 
You're the first you're the last my ______"

Which all encompassing word completes this Barry White lyric of love?
questions.explanation:
everything.

	Lyrics from Barry White's "You're My Everything". This song topped the UK charts in 1974. It peaked at #2 in the US.Barry White died in 2003.

questions.text:
"I drove all night to get to you 
Is that all right? 
I drove all night, ______ in your room 
Woke you from your sleep to make love to you."

How did Roy Orbison describe his big entrance into her room?
questions.explanation:
crept.

	Roy Orbison's career began in the 1950s. He had a string of around 30 UK hits in the 1960s. Roy, known as the "Big O", died in 1988. "I Drove All Night" was a 1992 UK chart hit.

questions.text:
"The problem is all inside your head she said to me 
The answer is easy if you take it logically 
I'd like to help you in your struggle to be free 
There must be ______ ways to leave your lover."

How many ways are there to commit this dastardly deed?
questions.explanation:
fifty.

	Paul Simon both wrote and sang this tune "50 Ways To Leave Your Lover". Released in the mid-seventies, it was a US chart topper peaking at #23 in the UK.

questions.text:
"Don't tell me it's not worth tryin' for 
You can't tell me it's not worth ______ for 
You know it's true 
Everything I do - I do it for you."

Emotional stuff, but what is the missing word from this Bryan Adams song?
questions.explanation:
dyin'.

	This track was a massive hit for Bryan Adams 1991. "(Everything I Do) I Do It For You" topped the charts in both the US and UK.

questions.text:
"Oh, what a night, late December back in ______ 
What a very special time for me 
As I remember what a night!"

In which year did this memorably night occur?
questions.explanation:
'63.

	"December '63 (Oh What A Night)" was a US and UK #1 hit for The Four Seasons in the mid-seventies. The group, featuring the falsetto vocals of Frankie Valli, had many hits in the early 1960s. After ten years in the doldrums the Four Seasons re-emerged in the mid-seventies for more chart success.

questions.text:
Not quite there yet, but how do Bon Jovi describe the situation?

"We're ______ there
Livin' on a prayer
Take my hand and we'll make it - I swear
Livin' on a prayer."
questions.explanation:
half way.

	"Livin' on a Prayer" topped the US chart and peaked at #4 in the UK charts in 1986. This Bon Jovi track featured on the album "Slippery When Wet".

questions.text:
Filling the space in this one should give you no problem.

"Are you lonesome tonight? 
Do you ______ me tonight? 
Are you sorry we drifted apart?"
questions.explanation:
miss.

	What's left to say about Elvis? This track was a massive hit 1960/61. "Are You Lonesome Tonight" remained at the top of the charts in the US and UK for many weeks.
